metadata.titleEn: A study on the prevalence and related factors of frailty and pre-frailty in the older population with hypertension in China: A national cross-sectional study
metadata.description:
Objective: To explore the prevalence and factors associated with frailty and pre-
frailty in elderly Chinese patients with hypertension.
Background: In China, there have been few national studies into the prevalence and
factors associated with frailty and pre-frailty in elderly patients with hypertension.
Methods: Through the 4th Sample Survey of Aged Population in Urban and Rural
China (SSAPUR) in 2015, the situation of hypertension subjects aged 60 years or
older in 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China
was obtained. And the frailty index was constructed based on 33 potential defects,
elderly hypertensive patients are classified as robust, frailty, and pre-frailty.
Results: A total of 76,801 elderly patients with hypertension were enrolled in the
study. The age-sex standardized prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in hypertensive
elderly in China was 16.1% (95%CI 15.8–16.3%), 58.1% (95%CI 57.7–58.4%). There
were significant geographical differences in the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty
in elderly hypertensive patients. Multinomial logistic regression analysis showed
that poor economic status, activities of daily living disability, and comorbid chronic
diseases were related to frailty and pre-frailty.
Conclusion: Frailty and pre-frailty are very common in elderly Chinese patients
with hypertension and have similar risk factors. Prevention strategies should be
developed to stop or delay the onset of frailty by targeting established risk factors
in the pre-frailty population of elderly hypertension. It is also crucial to optimize the
management of frailty in elderly Chinese patients with hypertension.

literatureList.titleEn: Zeng, X. Z., Jia, N., Meng, L. B., Shi, J., Li, Y. Y., Hu, J. B., Hu, X., Li, H., Xu, H. X., Li, J. Y., Qi, X., Wang, H., Zhang, Q. X., Li, J., & Liu, D. P. (2023). A study on the prevalence and related factors of frailty and pre-frailty in the older population with hypertension in China: A national cross-sectional study. Frontiers in cardiovascular medicine, 9, 1057361. https://doi.org/10.3389/fcvm.2022.1057361

A study on the prevalence and related factors of frailty and pre-frailty in the older population with hypertension in China: A national cross-sectional study. Frontiers in cardiovascular medicine, 9, 1057361. https://doi.org/10.3389/fcvm.2022.1057361

background: At least 50% of older adults suffer from hypertension, and the prevalence of hypertension in the elderly over 80 years is close to 90%. Hypertension is the foremost independent risk factor for stroke, myocardial infarction, and even cardiovascular death in older adults. Frailty is a non-specific state of progressive decline in the function and reserve of multiple systems, diminished homeostatic regulation of the body, and decreased compensatory capacity for physiological adaptation in response to stress in the elderly. Global community of elderly frail prevalence was 4–59%, and the average prevalence was 11%. A meta-analysis revealed that frail older hypertensive patients had a higher risk of death, hospitalization, and falls than older hypertensive patients who were not frail. Studies have shown that frailty is a factor that must be considered in setting target blood pressure levels for elderly patients with hypertension. European Society of Hypertension, European Geriatric Medicine Society, and the 2019 Chinese Guideline for Hypertensive elderly all clearly emphasize that frailty assessment as a concern in the management of hypertension in the elderly.
research objective: This study aimed to find the prevalence and factors of frailty and pre-frailty in elderly Chinese patients with hypertension in various provinces, municipalities, and autonomous regions in mainland China and provide a basis for the management of older hypertensive patients with frailty.
challenges: However, the sample is not rich in frail individuals, and the selection of rural Beijing and rural Chengdu as representatives of rural northern and southern China limited the generalization of the findings.
methods: In our study, we used data from the 4th SSAPUR in 2015; we then assessed the frailty and pre-frailty of elderly hypertensive patients by using the frailty index (FI). Content from the 4th SSAPUR, a cross-sectional study of elderly subjects aged 60 years or older from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China was obtained. The number of samples collected by SSAPUR was 224,142, of which 15,756 (7.0%) were excluded because the number of constructed FI items was less than 28. Among the 208,386 older individuals, 76,801 physician-diagnosed elderly patients with hypertension were enrolled in our study. We constructed FI following Searle’s standard procedure. SPSS 24.0 software was used for analysis. Missing data were interpolated using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) multiple fill method. Age-sex standardized prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty among elderly patients with hypertension in China was calculated according to the weights created in our study. We assessed the significance of differences by ANOVA or Student’s t-test for continuous variables and by the χ2 test for categorical variables. Multinomial regression analysis were used to ascertain the factors associated with frailty and pre-frailty, including comorbidities, ADL disability, southern or northern China, age group, sex, nationality, residence location, education level, marital status, living alone, economic status, medical insurance, the convenience of medical expense reimbursement.
dataset: The number of samples collected by SSAPUR was 224,142, of which 15,756 (7.0%) were excluded because the number of constructed FI items was less than 28. Among the 208,386 older individuals, 76,801 physician-diagnosed elderly patients with hypertension were enrolled in our study.
findings: Our study reported a higher prevalence of frailty in elderly hypertensive patients than a previous study, Ma et al. reported a 13.8% prevalence of frailty in a national study that included 3,844 elderly hypertensive patients in a comprehensive assessment of the elderly in China. Our large nationally representative sample study found that frail older hypertensive patients were older and had higher rates of hospitalization in the past year, ADL disability and comorbid chronic diseases compared to non-frail older hypertensive patients. These characteristics suggest that frail older hypertensive patients are prone to adverse events. We found that the frailty prevalence of older hypertensive patients in the economically underdeveloped western and northern regions was relatively high, while the economically developed coastal areas were relatively low.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method for a dataset on frailty in elderly hypertensive patients in China include a standardized procedure like the frailty index (FI)?
Is it possible to determine the economic status of elderly hypertensive patients from a dataset aimed at assessing frailty in China?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the frailty index (FI) or another index more commonly used for assessing frailty in elderly hypertensive patients in China?
Do data collection methods for studying frailty in elderly hypertensive patients prioritize cross-sectional surveys or longitudinal studies?

Concept Completion.Question: What methods are used to assess frailty and pre-frailty among elderly hypertensive patients in China?
Where are the regional differences in the prevalence of frailty among elderly hypertensive patients in China most pronounced?
Concept Completion.Answer: economically underdeveloped western and northern regions

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges exist in generalizing findings about frailty prevalence among elderly hypertensive patients in China?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to assess frailty in elderly hypertensive patients across different regions in China?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used is the 4th Survey of the Sampling Population in Urban and Rural China (SSAPUR) conducted in 2015, which included elderly subjects aged 60 years or older from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China. This cross-sectional study assessed frailty using the frailty index (FI).

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting data on frailty among elderly hypertensive patients in rural areas of China?
Example.Answer: A challenge in collecting data is the limited representation of frail individuals, as seen in the selection of rural Beijing and rural Chengdu as representatives of rural northern and southern China, which limits the generalization of the findings.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used in research to analyze the prevalence and factors of frailty in elderly hypertensive patients in China?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used in this research is the dataset collected by SSAPUR, which initially included 224,142 individuals. After excluding those with insufficient data for constructing the frailty index, the dataset comprised 76,801 elderly patients with hypertension.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes are used to construct a frailty index for elderly hypertensive patients?
What are the factors influencing regional differences in frailty and pre-frailty prevalence among elderly hypertensive patients in China?
Feature Specification.Answer: economic status, ADL disability, chronic disease comorbidities

Quantification.Question: How many older individuals were included in the data collection process for assessing frailty and pre-frailty in elderly hypertensive patients?
What percentage of the collected samples were excluded due to insufficiently constructed frailty index items?
What is the prevalence of frailty among elderly hypertensive patients in China according to the age-sex standardized measurement?

Definition.Question: What is a frailty index in the context of evaluating elderly patients with hypertension?
Definition.Answer: A frailty index is a tool used to assess the level of frailty in elderly patients by considering multiple potential deficits. In the context of elderly patients with hypertension, it helps to categorize individuals into robust, prefrail, and frail states based on these deficits.

Definition.Question: What does it mean to use a cross-sectional study in the context of data collection for elderly hypertension research?
Definition.Answer: A cross-sectional study in this context refers to a research design that collects data from a population of elderly hypertensive patients at a single point in time. It is used to determine the prevalence of frailty and prefrailty as well as related factors among this group.

Comparison.Question: How does the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in elderly hypertensive patients differ between economically developed coastal areas and economically underdeveloped western and northern regions in China?
Comparison.Answer: The study found that frailty prevalence among older hypertensive patients was higher in economically underdeveloped western and northern regions compared to economically developed coastal areas. This suggests that economic status may influence health outcomes, possibly due to differences in healthcare access, lifestyle, and environmental factors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the regional differences in the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty among elderly hypertensive patients in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The regional differences in the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty among elderly hypertensive patients in China are significantly influenced by economic status, with economically underdeveloped regions in the western and northern areas showing relatively higher frailty prevalence compared to the economically developed coastal areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might some elderly hypertensive individuals be excluded from data collection in studies assessing frailty using a frailty index?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Elderly hypertensive individuals might be excluded from data collection if the number of constructed frailty index (FI) items is less than the minimum required threshold, as a comprehensive set of at least 28 FI items is necessary to adequately assess frailty.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What could be the underlying reasons for missing data in large-scale surveys of elderly hypertensive populations, and how might researchers address these issues?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Missing data in large-scale surveys of elderly hypertensive populations may arise due to incomplete responses or unavailability of certain data points. Researchers address these issues by using methods such as the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) multiple fill method to interpolate missing data, ensuring a more complete dataset for analysis.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of using a frailty index constructed from a limited number of items on the prevalence estimation of frailty in elderly hypertensive patients?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a frailty index constructed from a limited number of items may lead to excluding certain individuals from the analysis, potentially resulting in an underestimation of the prevalence of frailty among elderly hypertensive patients.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the choice of regional sampling locations influence the generalizability of findings in studies investigating frailty prevalence among elderly hypertensive populations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The choice of regional sampling locations can influence the generalizability of findings, as representing only certain areas, such as rural Beijing and rural Chengdu, may limit the applicability of results to other regions, potentially impacting the understanding of frailty prevalence across different economic and geographical settings.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to explore frailty and pre-frailty prevalence among elderly hypertensive patients across different regions in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The study aimed to find the prevalence and factors of frailty and pre-frailty in elderly Chinese patients with hypertension in various provinces, municipalities, and autonomous regions in mainland China and provide a basis for the management of older hypertensive patients with frailty.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of using a frailty index (FI) to assess elderly hypertensive patients?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The frailty index (FI) is used to assess the frailty and pre-frailty of elderly hypertensive patients, facilitating the identification of frail individuals and aiding in the management and prevention strategies for frailty in hypertension care among the elderly.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why focus on socioeconomic and regional factors when examining frailty in elderly hypertensive populations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The study found significant regional differences in the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty among elderly hypertensive patients, linking higher frailty rates to economically underdeveloped regions. This highlights the importance of socioeconomic and regional factors in understanding and managing frailty in this population.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures followed to construct a frailty index from potential deficits in elderly hypertensive patients?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The frailty index is constructed by following Searle’s standard procedure, which includes assessing and incorporating 33 potential deficits. SPSS 24.0 software is used for analysis, and missing data are interpolated using the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) multiple fill method.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the age-sex standardized prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty calculated among elderly patients with hypertension?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The age-sex standardized prevalence is calculated according to the weights created in the study. The significance of differences is assessed using ANOVA or Student’s t-test for continuous variables and the χ2 test for categorical variables.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological steps are taken to assess the factors associated with frailty and pre-frailty in elderly hypertensive patients?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multinomial regression analysis is used to ascertain the factors associated with frailty and pre-frailty, considering variables such as comorbidities, ADL disability, geographic region, age group, sex, nationality, residence location, education level, marital status, living alone, economic status, medical insurance, and the convenience of medical expense reimbursement.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable researchers to accurately assess frailty and pre-frailty in elderly hypertensive patients across diverse regions in China?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection method used involved a cross-sectional study utilizing the 4th SSAPUR data from 2015, which included elderly subjects aged 60 years or older from 31 provinces in mainland China. The frailty and pre-frailty of patients were assessed using a frailty index (FI) constructed according to Searle’s standard procedure.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of a frailty index enable a more nuanced understanding of the health status of elderly hypertensive patients?
Enablement.Answer: The frailty index (FI) enables a nuanced understanding by allowing categorization of elderly hypertensive patients into robust, frail, and pre-frail groups based on 33 potential deficits. This index facilitates the identification of specific health challenges and risk factors associated with frailty and pre-frailty.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or factors enable the identification of regional differences in frailty prevalence among elderly hypertensive patients in China?
Enablement.Answer: The identification of regional differences in frailty prevalence is enabled by analyzing data from a large, nationally representative sample that accounts for factors such as age, sex, economic status, ADL disability, comorbidities, and geographic location (southern or northern China). Multinomial regression analysis helps determine the significance of these factors.

Expectation.Question: Why might the sample not be rich in frail individuals despite the large dataset collected from a wide geographical area?
Expectation.Answer: The selection of rural Beijing and rural Chengdu as representatives of rural northern and southern China limited the generalization of the findings, which might contribute to the sample not being rich in frail individuals.

Expectation.Question: Why could there be significant regional differences in the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty among the elderly with hypertension in China?
Expectation.Answer: The frailty prevalence of older hypertensive patients in the economically underdeveloped western and northern regions was relatively high, while the economically developed coastal areas were relatively low, indicating significant regional differences.

Expectation.Question: What factors might contribute to the higher prevalence of frailty in elderly hypertensive patients compared to previous studies?
Expectation.Answer: The large nationally representative sample study found that frail older hypertensive patients were older, had higher rates of hospitalization in the past year, ADL disability, and comorbid chronic diseases compared to non-frail older hypertensive patients, which may contribute to the higher prevalence of frailty.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges associated with collecting data from a diverse range of provinces, municipalities, and autonomous regions across mainland China for a study on elderly hypertension and frailty?
Judgmental.Answer: Collecting data from a diverse range of regions in mainland China presents several challenges. There is significant regional variability in economic development, healthcare access, and demographic factors, which can introduce biases. The study found differences in frailty prevalence between economically developed coastal areas and underdeveloped regions, which could complicate data interpretation. Additionally, logistical challenges in reaching remote areas and ensuring consistent data collection methods across varied settings may pose difficulties. These factors must be carefully managed to ensure the data's validity and representativeness.

Assertion.Question: I'm not clear on how a dataset for frailty in elderly hypertensive patients can be constructed to capture regional differences across various provinces in China.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset uses data from the 4th SSAPUR, a cross-sectional study involving subjects aged 60 years or older from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China. It accounts for regional differences by including variables like southern or northern China, residence location, and economic status.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges faced in ensuring the representativeness of a dataset when assessing frailty prevalence in elderly hypertensive populations.
Assertion.Answer: One challenge in ensuring representativeness is the selection of representative rural areas, as seen with the choice of rural Beijing and rural Chengdu, which may limit the generalization of findings to other rural areas in China.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize the data collection methods used to gather information on frailty and pre-frailty prevalence among elderly hypertensive patients in various regions of China.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection was conducted via the 4th China Urban and Rural Elderly Population Sampling Survey (SSAPUR) in 2015, involving a cross-sectional study of elderly subjects aged 60 years or older across 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China. The study focused on constructing a frailty index (FI) using 33 potential health deficits to assess frailty and pre-frailty among elderly hypertensive patients.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and analyze the challenges encountered in collecting comprehensive data on frailty and pre-frailty among elderly populations with hypertension in China.
Request/Directive.Answer: One challenge identified was the limited representation of frail individuals due to the selection of rural Beijing and rural Chengdu as representatives of rural northern and southern China, which restricted the generalization of the findings. Additionally, a portion of the samples was excluded because the number of constructed FI items was less than 28.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential datasets that could complement the data on frailty and pre-frailty prevalence in elderly hypertensive patients in China, focusing on expanding the geographical and demographic scope.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential dataset for complementing the existing data could involve expanding the geographical scope to include more diverse rural and urban areas beyond Beijing and Chengdu. This would enhance the representativeness of the sample. Additionally, integrating data from other national health surveys or regional studies that capture similar demographic and health information could provide a more comprehensive understanding of frailty and pre-frailty prevalence among elderly hypertensive populations.
